4150/A0/05/883/002.indicator_name: Number of facilities providing adolescent friendly services in line with international standards and good practices

4150/A0/05/883/002.headline: Adolescents  including the most disadvantaged  demand for and have access to quality youth-friendly information  services and capacity development

4150/A0/04/002/001.indicator_name: % of children 4-6 with access to early childhood education and development
The TLSS 2007 revealed that 27% of parents indicated that they prefer to keep their preschool children at home and 11% indicated that their children are too young to attend preschool.
Innovative ECE/ECD media materials (including TV programmes) directed at both parents and young children are developed  piloted and promoted to cover preschool age children at homes

Programme standards (input and process) for quality and cost-efficient ECE settings are revised and adopted. M&E framework for alternative ECE services are developed and endorsed by the MoE  ELDS based preschool programme  child-centred teacher training package and relevant reading materials are developed  endorsed by MoE and used by both state and alternative ECE settings  Monitoring of learning outcomes tools embeded into government quality assurance system

Clear normative and regulatory framework enabling provision of low cost and quality ECE services is adopted. (Revised normative and regulatory acts should address bureaucratic and burdensome taxation procedures that hinder provision of low cost ECE services)

Evidenced-based proposal for increased allocation for ECE is put forward by MoE in its next submission for MTEF  New mechanisms for ECE funding/financing (PCF) aimed at increased transparency  objectivity and predictability in the budget allocation process are introduced
Conceptual framework for monitoring of ECE is developed and ECE quantitative and quality indicators are incorporated into the MoE administrative database (EMIS) and tracked on annual basis

Material technical base of alternative ECE settings (Gov't ones) are improved with adequate  age appropriate  relevant and quality books  learning tools  toys and furniture  Teacher training (in-service) for alternative ECE programmes is institutionalised  Effective system for professional development of teachers and a performance management and monitoring system that is welcomed and supported by the teaching cadre is strengthened
% of children 4-6 enrolled in ECE settings in selected areas  % of CWD enrolled in ECE settings

Funds to establish alternative ECE settings are leveraged from different sources (government  donors and private)  Clear cost sharing and transparent funding mechanisms for alternative ECE services and gradual take-over of recurring costs (salary) by government/local budget are identified and agreed upon  New mechanisms of ECE funding/financing aimed at increased transparency  objectivity and predictability in the budget allocation process with best cost sharing options (among local budgets and
Number of ECE centres with properly regulated mechanisms for financial (cash flows) and operational management

4150/A0/04/002/001.status_value: ELDS  endorsed in 2009  was revisited in 2015 to comply with international standards    State Standards on Preschool Education was revised and adopted by the Government of Tajikistan in 2015   Regulation on Preschool Education  including ECE settings  was revised and adopted by the Government of Tajikistan in 2015   Learning Outcome Assessment tool for ECE settings was developed and is being piloted in 30 ECE centres since October 2015.
4150/A0/04/002/001.indicator_name: The MoE applies the National Early Learning Strategy and ELDS-based pre-school programme
4150/A0/04/002/001.baseline_value: No clear national strategy on Early Childhood Education  absence of ELDS  absence of ELDS based preschool programme  no clear enabling regulatory environment for provision of ECE services in the country

4150/A0/04/002/001.status_value: 23 ECE centres in Sughd Region and 4 ECE centres in Rasht Valley were established adding up to 207 ECE centres  supported by UNICEF to provide low cost and quality ECE services to preschool age children  including ethnic minorities.
4150/A0/04/002/001.indicator_name: Number of cost efficient  half day ECE settings in 12 priority districts
4150/A0/04/002/001.baseline_value: 1. 13 ECE groups in 6 schools and 1 community in Rasht (8) and Shugnan (5) districts 2. 21 Child-to-Child groups in Bokhtar and 17 Child-to-Child groups in J. Rumi

4150/A0/04/002/003.status_value: A total of 140 schools have received WASH hardware interventions: 25 Schools in 6 priority districts received new latrines  50 project schools in 5 districts received bio sand water filters and hand washing facilities  15 schools in 3 priority districts with improvement of access to safe drinking water through water supply repairs  Not on track to meet targets due to various constraints.
4150/A0/04/002/003.indicator_name: The percentage of schools with safe water supply and sanitation facilities in twelve priority districts
4150/A0/04/002/003.baseline_value: 173 schools out of 856 schools in twelve priority districts covered (20%)

4150/A0/04/002/002.status_value: 215 schools in 7 priority districts implement specific interventions to improve girls enrolment and attendance in grades 7-9  98 schools in 7 priority districts received thematic funding to prevent drop-out among girls  100 schools in priority districts received 2000 sets of school desks and chairs  100 bookshelves for classrooms  90 tables and chairs for teachers  250 blackboards  100 bookshelves for school libraries  42 000 books (109 names)  for school libraries  250 School-in-a-bag sets and
4150/A0/04/002/002.indicator_name: Number of schools in twelve priority districts introducing specific interventions to retain girls at school
4150/A0/04/002/002.baseline_value: 50 schools out of 856 schools in twelve priority districts received thematic funding to prevent drop-out among girls

4150/A0/04/002/005.status_value: As of 31 December 2013  539 secondary schools are covered by LSBE program. In 2013 alone  132 schools were covered  thus exceeding the target of 489 by 50 schools.
4150/A0/04/002/005.indicator_name: Number of schools using the approved LSBHE learning manuals in teaching practice
4150/A0/04/002/005.baseline_value: 200 secondary schools out of 856 secondary schools in twelve priority districts covered(the total number of schools supported by UNICEF as of 2009)

4150/A0/04/002/004.status_value: In 2013  an additional 10 schools are covered by DIPECHO project reaching the target number of 536 schools. However it should be noted that in 26 schools the programme has been implemented comprehensively (trainings  simulation drills  non-structural mitigation  provision of equipment and IEC materials)  while 510 schools were only covered via distribution of IEC materials. No simulation exercises or distribution of equipment were envisaged in those 510 schools.
4150/A0/04/002/004.indicator_name: Number of schools conducting DRR activities

4150/A0/04/002/007.status_value: 2 regulations on multi-grade schools have been revised and submitted to the Government for approval.
4150/A0/04/002/007.indicator_name: No. of regulations that will strengthen multigrade teaching and learning

4150/A0/04/002/007.status_value: 60 (36 female  24 male) faculty members/teachers trained in pedagogical approaches  and further 20 will be trained in the 2015-2016 academic year. 560 students are enrolled in Pedagogical mastery course in 2015.   60 school teachers received an advanced training on Inclusive Education within resource centres.    63 teachers and school administrators are trained in teaching and learning in Multi-grade classrooms.
4150/A0/04/002/007.indicator_name: No. of teachers trained at both pre-service and in-service levels to improve teaching methodologies affecting the quality of education
No. of teachers of multigrade supported through training and appropriate materials that increase their capacity to teach in a complex  rural  setting.
Increased demand for quality education amongst parents and community members.
Improve demand and enrolment rates of students typically excluded from or marginalised in mainstream education.
# of teachers trained in student-centred and varied pedagogical methods to promote and ensure improved quality of education in Tajikistan.

The quality of education is addressed through the introduction and implementation of Inclusive Education  which will ensure learning environments that are welcoming to all students  with particular attention to children with disabilities.
Multigrade policies are in place to provide a supportive framework for teaching and learning in multigrade settings
Coefficients introduced into the PCF formula to support small  rural  multigrade schools to ensure quality education.
A coordinated mechanism is established within the education sector and cross-sectorally to promote Inclusive Education as a means for improving quality education
Availability teaching and learning materials at the district and school-level to support multigrade classrooms as well as student-centre and inclusive approaches to education.

4150/A0/04/002/006.status_value: 2 definitions developed (to define Absenteeism and Drop-Out at the National level) and approved in the regulation  1 regulation on ALP has been developed.
4150/A0/04/002/006.indicator_name: No. of regulations that will strengthen the identification of OOSC  the prevention of drop-out and the re-entry of children in formal or non-formal education to complete basic education

4150/A0/04/002/006.status_value: 71 schools have specific interventions to enrol and retain children  implementing the Early Warning System and/or a programme to encourage girls' transition to secondary school.
4150/A0/04/002/006.indicator_name: No. of schools and institutions with specific interventions to enrol and retain children in basic education

4150/A0/04/002/006.status_value: 71 (28 boys and 43 girls) students are enrolled in the ALP.
4150/A0/04/002/006.indicator_name: Number of children enrolled in the ALP
No. of trained teachers and other education stakeholders on ALP.
The percentage of girls completing their compulsory education and transitioning to secondary education is increased.
Costs of education to families are analysed and financial barriers to education addressed to reduce the number of OOSC.
Parents and communities are aware of the importance of education (both formal and non-formal to support the ALP) and parents and communities support their children's learning.
Clear guidelines and policies on re-entry to basic education and placement of overage children in formal education are adopted.
The regulatory framework will be strengthened with protocols on absentee management and defining of key indicators (drop-out  absenteeism  at-risk).
Ensure financing mechanisms for non-formal and ALP to ensure sustained approach and equal opportunities.
EMIS reports include statistics and analysis on numbers and trends with regard to OOSC and dropouts and absenteeism.
ALP with multiple implementation modalities is designed and adopted to reach the maximum number of OOSC

4150/A0/04/001/004.indicator_name: Proportion of HIV positive pregnant women who received PMTCT services according to national protocols
Number of reported cases of stigma and discrimination towards HIV positive pregnant women at ANC centres
Proportion of HIV positive children and adolescents who have access to child friendly rooms to improve their quality of life
Proportion of HIV positive pregnant women who received PMTCT services according to the updated PMTCT protocol including B+ strategy  which supports continuous access
Endorsed National Policy on PMTCT Programming Scaling-Up disseminated throughout the country

Proportion of health service providers in ANC equipped with knowledge and skills on PMTCT. Number of health specialists providing ART to HIV positive pregnant women in line with the national PMTCT protocol.
ART drugs are available for all HIV+ pregnant women and newborn children to prevent HIV transmission from mother-to-child.
Mechanism for coordination and continunity between MCH and AIDS centers operational at regional level.

National instruction is in place to support MoH to increase domestic expenditure and procure the HIV tests. Proportion of pregnant women covered by HIV testing  financially supported by the government.
Per cent of pregnant women with at risk profile received VCT at antenatal care
Percentage of HIV+ children receiving social allowances

4150/A0/05/884/002.status_value: 170 children who committed a minor offence were diverted from the criminal justice system and referred to the Centres for Additional Education (CAEs) in six districts of Sughd (151 - (130 boys / 21 girls)) and Khatlon (19) regions between January and November. 4150/A0/05/884/003.status_value: A baseline study on Knowledge  Attitudes  Behaviours and Practices related to children and women with disabilities was completed. A household survey was conduced among 2 000 respondents throughout the country. In addition  24 FGD and 19 key informant interviews were carried out.

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: There are 7 child-friendly courtrooms staffed with trained judges and equipped with CCTV. The last such courtroom to be officially opened was in Kulob in May 2015.
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Number of child friendly court rooms staffed with specially assigned and trained judges and using adapted procedures

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: The  approval from Government stakeholders to use the Protocol is still pending. The Protocol was resubmitted to newly appointed senior staff of the Council of Justice in June 2015.
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Existence and use of a protocol between police  prosecutor and judges to avoid double victimisation of child victims
Percentage of child victims' investigations handled by trained staff in the child friendly courts'

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: Pre-service training on child rights was established in the TNU for law students and in the Police Academy for future police officers.  Training packages for judges and prosecutors were finalized and shared with the Government to lay the ground for in-service training of mentioned professionals.  In June 2015  initial discussion was held with the newly appointed staff of the Council of Justice on mainstreaming child rights and justice for children into the pre-service training curriculum of judg
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Existence of a regular in -service  pre-service training on JJ for justice professionals
4150/A0/04/003/003.baseline_value: Pre-service only in Police Academy and TNU Law School

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: 42 newly appointed judges and 60 Council of Justice trainee-judges were trained in Sept-Dec 2015 with UNICEF support. In addition  20 prosecutors and 200 police cadets were trained with Government funds.
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Number of continuously and specially trained juvenile justice (JJ) professionals from 15 districts

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: 74 cases registered (19 written complaints and 55 oral consultations).
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Number of complaints handled by the Child Rights Department of the Ombudsman Office per year

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: Not developed yet. Documents are in the discussion phase with the Government
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Existence and use of a protocol between police  prosecutor and judges to avoid double victimisation of child victims
Percentage of child victims' investigations handled by trained staff in the child friendly courts'
Number of complaints handled by the Child Rights Department of the Ombudsman Office per year

High level decision makers are supportive of reform of the closed institutions as indicated in the NPA for JJ. Advocacy and awareness raising activities (trainings held with stakeholders  articles in newspapers  shows in TV and radio) for mindset change regarding children in need of support  not isolation

1) NPA for JJ is revised with clear division of responsibilities  timeframe and resources  2) amendments are adopted in the national legislation:-amendment are made in the Criminal Code to obligate referral to community-based programs  amendments are made in Criminal Procedure Code (CPC) to reduce 72 hours of police custody without a court order  arrest protocols must have indication of name and position of interrogating police officer.

Proposals of relevant government bodies involved in JJ reform to the Ministry of Finance on increasing the budget allocation. Reallocation of existing budget by relevant sectors to be used more effectively for implementation of the NPA for JJ
Government decision appointing a full-time body (Ministry of Justice) to coordinate the juvenile justice system reform
Vocational training for children in conflict with the law are equipped with the requisite supplies.
a) Availability of pre and in service training for SW  police and judiciary  b) Number of officially recruited and specially trained social workers  police and judiciary working in the JJ system
Trained lawyers provide free of charge quality legal assistance to children from poor families. JJAP in CAEs are provided resources to reach out to children
Awareness raising activities (articles in newspapers  shows in TV and radio) for mindset change on children with difficult behaviour in need of support  not isolation

1) the practice is in place (MoU/agreement between MoJ  MLSP  MoE  etc.) to support released children as provided in the legislation  2) number of children released from the juvenile colony who are supported by relevant agencies in re-integration back into society  employment and further psychosocial counselling

Juvenile Justice Alternative Project staff in Centres for Additional Education (CAE) are trained and receive on the job supervision and guidance.  District based CAEs are providing legal and psychosocial support.

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: There are 3 courtrooms staffed with special CCTV equipment and trained judges.
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Number of child friendly court rooms staffed with specially assigned and trained judges

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: Pre-service training on child rights is established in the TNU for law students. Training packages for judges and prosecutors are under finalization  which will lay ground for in-service training the mentioned professionals.
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Existance of a regular in -service  preservice training on JJ for justice professionals

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: More than 250 judges  180 police officers  45 prosecutors  20 defence lawyers and the staff of the Child Rights Units from the JJAP districts were trained on international and national standards of child rights justice for children. Out of 250  20 judges who hear children's cases are receiving continuous training since 2012.
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Number specially trained JJ professionals to work with children

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: 7 districts are implementing the JJAP according to the guidelines.
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Number of available districts implementing Juvenile Justice Alternative Project (JJAP)

4150/A0/04/003/003.status_value: 216 children referred to the JJAP since 2012 in 14 districts.
4150/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Number of children in conflict with the law refered to JJAPs
